abstract.p: Thomas J Crowley letter comments on June 27 analysis of Pres Clinton's speech at United Nations on environment; contends that statistical studies suggest that we are already on verge of detecting a greenhouse warming

block.p: Your June 27 news analysis of President Clinton's speech at the United Nations on the environment says that greenhouse gases threaten to ''seriously disrupt the climate 100 or 200 years from now.''
Your June 27 news analysis of President Clinton's speech at the United Nations on the environment says that greenhouse gases threaten to ''seriously disrupt the climate 100 or 200 years from now.''

Such phrasing leaves the impression that the effect is so far off that delays in implementing restrictions can be contemplated with leisure. However, statistical studies suggest that we are already on the verge of detecting a greenhouse warming.
If the projections for the middle of the next century are correct, global temperatures will have increased to a level that has not occurred since the evolution of man.

This implies that children now in school will witness such a climate change. Perhaps if policy makers could visualize such long-term projections, they might be able to deal with the implications in a less abstract manner.
THOMAS J. CROWLEY College Station, Tex., June 28, 1997
The writer is a professor of oceanography at Texas A & M.
